newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-PRICE TAKES TWO-SHOT LEAD INTO FINAL ROUND AT HERITAGE.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-PRICE TAKES TWO-SHOT LEAD INTO FINAL ROUND AT HERITAGE.

text.p: Nick Price moved closer to his first PGA Tour victory in three
years by taking a two-stroke lead after three rounds at the
$1.5 million Heritage Classic Saturday.
Price birdied the final hole in a stiff breeze whipping
off Calibogue Sound to card a respectable two-under-par 69 on
the tight Harbour Town course.
The Zimbabwean posted a 10-under 203 total with one round
left. American Brad Faxon (70) was second at 205, British Open
champion Tom Lehman (67) was three shots back, while
eight-time major winner Tom Watson (70) joined Lennie Clements
(73) five shots off the pace.
"I hit the ball very solidly all day," said Price. "The
wind switched today, which made it a little tougher to read. I
made a couple of mistakes through wrong club selection or
misreading the wind.
"The dropped shots I'm making are coming from mental
mistakes, not physical mistakes. When I did make a mistake I
chipped well or holed a putt. It was a very positive day for
me. There's nothing better than playing well under pressure.
That's the ultimate kick."
Price, winner of three major titles, has not trimphed on
the PGA Tour since the Canadian Open in September, 1994, but
he has won five times in Africa since then, including twice
against good fields at the Dimension Data Pro-Am and South
African PGA Championship in South Africa in February.
"The win I had at Sun City was very satisfying, because I
kept going away from the field," Price said. "There was no
slacking off. It's nice when you haven't won in 14 months to
win going away."
Price, 39, was ranked number one in the world at the end
of 1994, but he dropped out of the top dozen late last year
before climbing back to his current ranking of ninth.
"I didn't hit a lot of good iron shots into the greens,"
Faxon said, "but I did a great job putting and scrambling for
pars."
Faxon, who won in New Orleans two weeks ago, said he is
"really psyched about playing with Nick. The last round we
played together was the third round at Turnberry at the
British Open when he won (in 1994). We both played great that
day."
Third-placed Lehman said: "I feel more focused than I have
been for a while. There have been times this year where I have
hit a shot and I wasn't even thinking about that shot. This
week I have been more tuned in."
